posts.name: Wilson
posts.cooked:
I’m aware of other topics addressing this but they have since been closed and I wish to bring this up again.

Live scores being published from the FMS would be a huge advantage to all teams. While it is useful to have them shown behind the new team number displays, it is often awkward to squint up at it in the heat of a close match. By publishing it to the fms, all teams have a fair opportunity to see the score without having to run over to the score display or look off to the scoreboard. It also opens the door to more complex robot logic, for example, 6328’s automation on the reef could switch from rank point to top-down automation if it detects a close score.

As a disclaimer, I do not fully know how the fms works so I do not know if this is a feasible change. I just see it as a benefit to teams with no disadvantage.

posts.name: seg9585
posts.cooked: Man between this and AI driven scouting + performance analysis, you’re taking all the fun out of drive coaching!

posts.name: Dan Peled
posts.cooked:
One of the important things in my opinion for any competition and especially for FIRST competitions is the fact that you cant access stuff like that, which forces you to interact with the other team’s via human interaction and think outside the box, if the robot was always aware of the entire state of the game, what would be the point of even having a coach? You would just have your robot tell you the right strategy / do it for you, which takes all the actual competitive skills out of the equation and leaves only the team’s programming skills

TLDR; I think that a feature like that takes some of the fun out of the competition and challenges of the game, and will be a negative influence on team interactivity

posts.name: seg9585
posts.cooked:
I asked a bunch of F1 fans why they like racing.  At first they said because of the fast speeds and cool cars.  I asked if they would still watch if the humans in the cars were replaced by remote operation or autonomous driving, enabling even faster cars and higher G loading.  They said no… so it’s not really about the cars, is it?  It’s about the people.

I’m curious how many years away FRC is from a fully autonomous robot that requires no drive team at all.  The team simply places the robot on the field and walks away.  It will happen at some point in sure, and we will all be in awe.  Then every team will do it and no one will watch anymore.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
seg9585:

I’m curious how many years away FRC is from a fully autonomous robot that requires no drive team at all

An infinite number of years IMO.

Driving robots is fun. This is a competition to teach skills, not a technology demo.

Just my opinion.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked:
I don’t know if you can even pass the clock time to the robot code. Can you? Otherwise automated end games would be a thing.

Or are they already?

seg9585:

F1 fans why they like racing

On that thread, I love the strategic decision making. All the data in the world and it still comes down to a couple of people making call.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Zook:

Otherwise automated end games would be a thing

It has been a long time since I have done code related stuff, but it has been a thing for sure in the past. See 2011 minibot automatic deployment.

The clock and driver station the team is at seems about the right amount of info IMO.

Zook:

I don’t know if you can even pass the clock time to the robot code. Can you? Otherwise automated end games would be a thing.

It’s available by default from WPILib, though not guaranteed to be accurate.

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
Dan1:

what would be the point of even having a coach? You would just have your robot tell you the right strategy / do it for you

There’s nothing stopping teams from repeating the data from the scoreboard to their robot via a dashboard (many did this year with scored reef positions), yet they still had coaches.

posts.name: Wilson
posts.cooked:
seg9585:

I’m curious how many years away FRC is from a fully autonomous robot that requires no drive team at all.

This is kind of off the topic of the thread, but I’d argue very far away. The randomness in a match, the defense, the random quirks of each robot can’t possibly all be programmed into two months of the season. Keep in mind that programming students turn over every 4 years, so unless a team has very strong mentors it would be hard to maintain fully automated systems. Plus I’d like to think most students would rather drive and risk being slightly less competitive than have a robot fully/mostly autonomous.

posts.name: Wilson
posts.cooked:
As a programming member, I suggest this feature with the idea of live viewing on a dashboard. I can’t see many teams using this feature for automation, I pointed out 6328 as an extreme case of a very strong programming team.

This feature would make it much more fair for both alliances, as this year there were many venues where the scoreboard visibility was much worse on one side of the field. This put one alliance at a disadvantage, and while some coaches may enjoy the responsibility of bending their necks and squinting, I don’t see why not just put it on a dashboard.

posts.name: Abdullah Khaled
posts.cooked:
Zook:

Otherwise automated end games would be a thing.

I think this relates to this post , as teams (at least this year) had to decide based on a number of factors in the moment whether to go for the endgame or try to eke out a few more cycles. Although I wasn’t on the drive team, as the technician I often saw how endgame choices changed during the match based on score, our alliance partners, and “feel.”

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: I speak for the trees, not for my team.

posts.custom_user_title: I speak for the trees, not for my team.

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked:
Crazy idea… bring two camera, and point them at the screen from the driver station. Use detection to read the number.

Transmit that data to the robot

Boom.

(I know this is not really feasible but it’s a fun idea)

posts.name: GaryVoshol
posts.cooked:
Skyehawk:

See 2011 minibot automatic deployment.

Which didn’t always exactly match the field time display, causing some disagreements when a minibot was flagged for deploying too soon.

posts.name: seg9585
posts.cooked:
Zook:

I don’t know if you can even pass the clock time to the robot code. Can you?

Yes – DriverStation.getMatchTime(); We’ve used this in our code so far for things like changing LED patterns and buzzing the controller for endgame.  We’ve been considering using it for auto mode decision making (time remaining to go for scoring vs making use of time in better ways like staging to collect next game piece)

I think most of the replies here are about whether they want to see a fully autonomous robot vs having drivers, not whether it’s technically capable of making it happen with current hardware.  If it’s technically capable, I guarantee at least a few teams will explore it.  At first maybe not in official matches but surely as demos and exhibition matches.

This year I observed maybe teams are “almost there” already.  4415’s switch panel just told the robot which position to score on and the robot did that, some matches the driver made a few if any control tweaks.  Their endgame climb was also autonomous.  Add in some logic tracking (or detecting) where game pieces have already scored, and it could potentially be exhibition ready   (I challenge you to do this, 4415!!). This is why I think it will be accomplished within the next 5-8 years.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
The closest I have seen was 1690 in 2022. If I am recalling correctly they had a “hold fire” button, but most of the time the robot was shooting on its own when it had a lock.

2015 may have been the game that it has been most possible.

There is a long way between “tell robot to score in this controlled manner once I have a game-piece” and " aquire gampieces and score under ever compounding error and other team induced randomness".

If there is a team that is doing well with a fully auto teleop, defense (if allowed) or other forms of “randomness” will be pretty effective I suspect. At the same time the team with the auto is not getting experience driving should they need to manually take over.

I will admit, it would be a lot of fun to see a team try to solve for defense/ edge cases, but the resources expended to do that will make them uncompetitive if it starts to go sideways.

/end ramble

posts.name: Levi
posts.cooked: I don’t see it mentioned so I would like to point out that the live scores are often inaccurate or at the very least delayed. I wouldn’t want my robot code depending on it

posts.name: Richard Wallace
posts.cooked: This especially true when there is a dodgy automated scoring sensor, or a manual scoring situation that can momentarily overload a volunteer.  Both happen too frequently and require a fully engaged coach to make fast decisions.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Space13:

the idea of live viewing on a dashboard

With the new (ish) team number signs, there is actually info displayed back to teams including the match time and current score (just not score breakdowns).

posts.name: Nadav
posts.cooked:
seg9585:

I asked a bunch of F1 fans why they like racing. At first they said because of the fast speeds and cool cars. I asked if they would still watch if the humans in the cars were replaced by remote operation or autonomous driving, enabling even faster cars and higher G loading. They said no… so it’s not really about the cars, is it? It’s about the people.

What about the memes?
